text.p: Here are the highlights from Swiss newspapers on Wednesday:
- A Georgetown, Cayman Islands court approved the extradition of bankrupt Swiss real estate dealer Peter Krueger to Switzerland, where he faces various fraud charges.
- Swiss consumption of industrially-produced pasta noodles rose after a two year decline by 1.8 percent to 67.7 million kilos in 1996. Per capita consumption averages 9.5 kilos annually.
- Chocolate producer Lindt & Spruengli's 1996 profit rose by 10.4 percent to 46.8 million Swiss francs.
- Swiss electronics firm Sprecher + Schuh AG, which U.S. technology group Rockwell took over in 1993, changed its name to Rockwell Automation AG.

- Seven high school students in Berne who created a solidarity fund for Holocaust victims have raised over 50,000 Swiss francs so far, 30,000 of which has been transfered to the Israeli aid organisation Amcha.
- The number of applications for building permits in Switzerland fell by 1.3 percent to 6,217 in the first quarter of 1997 compared to the same period in 1996.

- Lindt & Spruengli announced it will expand its existing chain of stores in the U.S. and expects to raise its share of the U.S. chocolate market by three percent to 18 percent. The company is also testing a new concept called "Pralines Post" at 350 post offices in Germany.
- European stock markets plunged after the U.S. market's two-day fall. The Swiss performance index fell by 3.4 percent.
